commander.name: Major-General Charles Keightley
commander.previous_service: Replaced Major General Charles Gairdner, led intensive training for overseas deployment

commander.headquarters_location: Tunisia - Blade Force advancing from Bone/Algiers toward Tunis

Humber Armoured Car Mk II.role: reconnaissance - Derbyshire Yeomanry B Squadron with Blade Force

Ordnance QF 25-pounder Gun-Howitzer (SP).note: Self-propelled artillery for armoured division mobility

Ordnance QF 6-pounder (57mm).note: Modern anti-tank gun for armoured division

supply_logistics.supply_status: STRAINED - Armoured division fuel consumption high during rapid advance. Extended supply lines from Bone (landed Nov 8) to Tunisia front. Heavy rains impede logistics. Competing with 78th Division and American forces for port capacity. Blade Force operating ahead of main supply echelons.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Tunisian countryside - hills, valleys, farmland. Heavy rains turn tracks to mud, limiting tank mobility. Mountainous border regions.

subordinate_units.equipment: 165 tanks (Crusader Mk II/III, Valentine Mk V)
subordinate_units.note: Tank regiments: 16th/5th Lancers, 17th/21st Lancers, 2nd Lothians and Border Horse. Blade Force formed from 17th/21st Lancers.
Motorised infantry for armoured division. Replaced 20th Armoured Brigade (April 1942). Part of Blade Force included 10th Rifle Brigade B Company.
Artillery, engineers, signals, reconnaissance (Derbyshire Yeomanry), transport, medical, workshops

tactical_doctrine.role: Armoured division for rapid exploitation during Operation Torch. 'Blade Force' spearheaded advance from Bone/Algiers into Tunisia ('Run for Tunis'). Mission: Seize Tunis and Bizerta before Axis reinforcement.
special_capabilities: Blade Force - combined arms battlegroup (tanks, motorised infantry, artillery, engineers)
Modern tanks (Crusader Mk III, Valentine Mk V) with good mobility
tactical_innovations: Blade Force concept - regimental battlegroup with combined arms (tank regiment + motorised infantry + support)
Rapid transition from sea landing to armoured advance
Integration of American light tank battalion into Blade Force
known_issues: No combat experience - first action at Operation Torch
Tunisian mud limits tank mobility (heavy rains November-December)
Extended supply lines strain fuel/ammunition availability
Crusader tanks mechanically unreliable in muddy conditions
Limited infantry support (only 38th Brigade for entire armoured division)
Rushed deployment - division not fully concentrated before combat
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: PARTIAL - Division trained for desert warfare but deployed to Tunisia. Tunisian terrain (hills, mud, rain) very different from expected desert conditions. Tanks struggle in mud. Division adapting to European-style terrain on the fly.

scenario_suitability: Armoured division in difficult terrain scenarios
special_rules: Fresh armoured division (full strength, modern tanks)
Blade Force battlegroup (combined arms mobility bonus)
Modern Crusader Mk III tanks (good mobility, thin armor)
Mud movement penalty (Tunisian rains reduce tank mobility 50%)
historical_engagements: Blade Force advance to Tunisia (12-28 November 1942)
